product_overview: PortfolioOS is an innovative, operating system-inspired interactive portfolio showcasing the skills, projects, and personal story of Rajath Hegde, a full-stack developer and MCA student. It transforms a traditional portfolio into a rich desktop experience with draggable windows, customizable themes, and multiple integrated applications reflecting a full OS environment.
core_goals: Provide a highly interactive, OS-like portfolio interface with window and desktop management.
Showcase personal and professional information through various content and utility applications.
Ensure accessibility and usability for all users, including those relying on assistive technologies.
Support responsive design covering desktop, tablet, and mobile devices for broad accessibility.
Offer extensive customization through themes, wallpapers, and system settings to personalize user experience.
Implement robust state management, persistence, and error handling for seamless UX.
Enable easy contact and communication via a validated and fully functional contact form.
key_features: Fully interactive desktop environment with draggable icons and customizable wallpaper selection.
Advanced window management with drag, resize, minimize, maximize, snap-to-edge, and keyboard shortcut support.
A suite of applications including About Me, Projects, Skills, Terminal, File Explorer, Web Browser, Media Player, Calculator, Weather, Notes, Settings, System Info, Gallery, Contact and more.
Comprehensive accessibility enhancements with ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, and screen reader support across all components.
Glassmorphism-based UI design supporting light, dark, and system theme modes with smooth visual effects and animations.
Notification center and system monitor with improved keyboard and focus management.
Local storage persistence for user preferences like window positions, icon layout, themes, and wallpapers.
Fully functional contact form with Zod validation, server-side email sending via Resend, and user feedback toasts.
Error boundaries across the application to prevent crashes and improve stability.
Responsive design adapting UI and controls for desktop, tablet, and mobile with touch gesture support.
user_flow_summary: User boots into PortfolioOS via a simulated login screen, entering any value or guest access to start.
Users interact with the desktop icons and taskbar to open various applications represented as draggable, resizable windows.
Users customize their environment via Settings app to change themes, wallpapers, sounds, and notifications.
Applications like Terminal and File Explorer provide command-line and file browsing capabilities with intuitive UX.
Users navigate notifications and search system-wide for apps or content via dedicated UI components.
Users fill out the Contact form with validations and submit messages securely, receiving toast notifications upon success or error.
Users on mobile devices access minimized windows via bottom navigation, while desktop users see a taskbar dock for window management.
validation_criteria: All UI components must pass accessibility audits with proper ARIA roles, labels, keyboard navigation, and screen reader compatibility.
Window management functions (drag, resize, minimize, maximize, snap) must be fully operational and perform smoothly.
Theme and wallpaper selections persist correctly between sessions via localStorage.
The contact form validates inputs client-side using Zod and successfully sends emails via the Resend API or simulates sending with fallback.
Notification center responds to keyboard and pointer interactions and properly manages focus and screen reader alerts.
Responsive design must adapt gracefully across desktop, tablet, and mobile with appropriate controls and layout adjustments.
Error boundaries must catch and handle runtime errors without crashing the entire app.
Performance optimizations such as lazy loading and animation smoothness must be verified.
End-to-end tests with Playwright confirm desktop functionality and no regressions.
Documentation and README accurately reflect features, usage, installation, and environment configuration.
